posts.cooked: Hi, I would like to edit a sticker pack I created, to include further stickers. Is this currently possible?

posts.name: link ‚ú¶
posts.cooked:
PPP1997:

Is this currently possible?

No, editing an uploaded sticker pack is not currently possible. The only option is to upload a new sticker pack and (if needed) distribute the new URL similar to how you did it previously.

As a side note, sticker packs you created aren‚Äôt actually linked to your Signal account in any way, even though an account is required to upload them:

Stickers are transmitted as standard encrypted attachments (with padding), and sticker packs are never associated with the creator‚Äôs Signal account.

(from the Make privacy stick blog post, emphasis mine)

posts.name: f00b4r
posts.cooked: If you are familiar with Python, downloading a pack, editing it and reuploading it is something you can do easily with my lib, and that I do on a regular basis. But yeah I‚Äôd love being able to do this with the Desktop client.

link_counts.title: GitHub - signalstickers/signalstickers-client: ‚öôÔ∏èüêç A Python client for the Signal stickers API

posts.name: link ‚ú¶
posts.cooked:
f00b4r:

downloading a pack, editing it and reuploading it is something you can do easily with my lib , and that I do on a regular basis

Just to be clear, I believe it still isn‚Äôt possible to re-upload the sticker pack with the same id and key (i.e. update an existing pack on the service), which I assumed the original question/request was about (I could be wrong, however).

The library could indeed help, depending on the level of the user‚Äôs familiarity with such things (as they won‚Äôt have to manually re-associate existing stickers with emoji, for example, and other details will be already there‚Äîunlike currently in Signal Desktop where they always start from scratch), but it‚Äôs not magic that allows you to do something that is not supported by the service at all.

posts.name: f00b4r
posts.cooked:
Just to be clear, I believe it still isn‚Äôt possible to re-upload the sticker pack with the same id and key

I wasn‚Äôt clear enough, sorry. Indeed, my answer is based on yours, it is not possible to edit a pack: the closest thing you can do is reupload another one with the same content, modulo your changes. Doing it programmatically will help recovering the content of the original pack, without having to do it manually (which can be veeeeery long for big packs). Sorry for the bad initial formulation!

Hello,

I‚Äôm happy to have found this thread because it seems that you have some experiences with sticker packs. I‚Äôve read the technical details how Signal Stickers work and it‚Äôs clear to me because you have to reupload a sticker pack when you would like to ‚Äúedit‚Äù it.
But using stickers in Signal it happened already multiple times that when I open the overview of a specific sticker pack I then have found new stickers in there‚Ä¶ I first thought that its only a mistake of my own and that I never saw the other stickers. But as it happened multiple times I now think that there is something going on‚Ä¶

The pack is this one: Install Signal stickers

My concern isn‚Äôt on the fact that it shouldn‚Äôt be possible to edit sticker packs - its more in a privacy way: if my observation is true, then Signal seems to download new stickers in a pack after these have been installed. So theoretically it could be possible to know if a specific user has installed a specific sticker pack (what in some cases - for some sticker packs - could give you information about the user).

Could you imagine that in some way the modification of a installed sticker pack is possible (when also not intended by the developers)?
Maybe you are forgetting which stickers were included in the pack. It is literally impossible to modify an uploaded sticker pack; the server doesn‚Äôt support that function.

posts.name: Michaeldrrc
posts.cooked:
Hello Signal Team,

I would like to see a feature to edit a sticker pack. Me and my friends have a funny collection of stickers we use. Its one of the best parts of us using signal. We would like to have one big collection to just dump all of our stickers into. Right now we have multiple sticker packs and it is quite annoying to know which stickers are where. Takes too long to find a sticker basically. Its just quite a hassle to create a sticker pack from scratch if we want to add one more sticker.

Thanks this would be a great addition

posts.name: Jj
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôve been trying to talk about this on this thread Stand alone stickers - Where I want to have stand alone stickers that can be copied without having to drag a full pack. I don‚Äôt want a new sticker pack tab in my stickers panel, I just want that image file available as a sticker.

And when I send it, that users can long-press and copy it locally. No packs involved. This allows to grow multiple stickers organically and making them disposable.

posts.name: Markus KARG
posts.cooked: As a professional design team we like to be able to replace an existing sticker pack with an updated one in case there is a bug in the sticker pack. For example, sometimes there are rendering issues we did not find before uploading, and we do not want that all our users have to manually replace version 1.0.0 by 1.0.1 just to get correctly rendered animations. Big plus 1 from us to allow updating the pack with UNCHANGED ID.

The problem with this feature is that it will allow an uploader to change the sticker pack in a malicious way after users already accepted the original one (e.g. by adding offensive or advertisement stickers to it).

posts.name: Markus KARG
posts.cooked: This is a legal issue that should be solved otherwise. As uploads are impossible in an anonymous way, there could simply be a bylaw established that forbid offensiveness and advertisement. This riks anyways is just 1%, while the benefit of being able to fix actual rendering bugs is 99%. If you don‚Äôt trust your supplier, then don‚Äôt install his packs.

mkarg:

If you don‚Äôt trust your supplier, then don‚Äôt install his packs.

I think the whole point is that you don‚Äôt have to trust the sticker set supplier.

However, making it possible to edit a sticker pack afterwards requires making sure only the original pack creator is able to do so, e.g. by providing a secret key.

Signal goes really hard into being intrinsically safe/secure for users, so they don‚Äôt need to investigate the source of a sticker pack to ensure that it won‚Äôt bite back in the future, it just can not happen once a pack is defined. Also, stickers and packs can be sent from an user to another, without a central distribution source to store this information (https://signalstickers.com is just an independent site, for example)

A legal or bylaw based approach won‚Äôt work too as it can‚Äôt be enforced: stickers are end-to-end encrypted and the server don‚Äôt know (by design) what‚Äôs inside them. To say nothing about the problem of defining ‚Äúlegal‚Äù and ‚Äúoffensive‚Äù in a universal way (e.g.: is the Taiwan flag legal in China?).

Users have the final word here and that‚Äôs a good thing.

mkarg:

sometimes there are rendering issues we did not find before uploading

Sounds like you just need a better review before uploading? If it‚Äôs not a major enough issue to notice right away, is it really that big of a deal?

posts.name: Markus KARG
posts.cooked: Don‚Äôt get ridiculous. After 30+ years in the software industry I can tell you that bugs DO happen even after VERY intensive testing. This includes rendering problems, too. In the end, we are giving away sticker sets for free, so you cannot REALLY ask us to invest hours of checks on each of our 100+ stickers in a set as an excuse for YOU not having either a bullet-proof update procedure OR bylaws that make it easy to prevent problems upfront.

mkarg:

In the end, we are giving away sticker sets for free, so you cannot REALLY ask us to invest hours of checks on each of our 100+ stickers in a set as an excuse for YOU not having either a bullet-proof update procedure OR bylaws that make it easy to prevent problems upfront.

I‚Äôm not sure why you‚Äôre talking as if you uploading free sticker packs is somehow providing a service to the Signal team and thus Signal owes you a specific feature. But really, what‚Äôs the problem with a rendering issue in a couple of stickers out of 100+ in a free sticker pack? It sounds like you‚Äôre taking your stickers a bit too seriously.

You also seem to have missed the point that Signal can‚Äôt make any meaningful ‚Äúbylaws‚Äù about their sticker packs because they were intentionally designed in such a way as to be anonymous and private ‚Äì the server has no knowledge of their contents or who the creator was, as @jamesholden pointed out.

By the way, I am just a volunteer moderator here, not a member of the Signal development team as you seem to think from the wording of your post.

posts.name: Markus KARG
posts.cooked:
Just because we provide our stickers for free does not mean that we won‚Äôt treat them with the same care as any of our paid products: There can be bugs, and we want a process to fix them without forcing everybody into re-installing a new bundle in their client.

We do not think Signal owes us anything. We just provide our opinion on the proposed update process applying our view as an ISV after decades of maintaining products. If Signal doesn‚Äôt follow our advice, we have and will accept that. But what we demand actually is that feature proposals are discussed by people that acutally can decide about them.

It‚Äôs a valid request; many people would probably like to be able to edit sticker packs. It‚Äôs just that it presents specific problems due to the nature of how it would work and is not easily done with the privacy-centric design. I‚Äôm sure the Signal team would like to provide that functionality if they can find a way to make it work within those constraints.

mkarg:

what we demand actually is that feature proposals are discussed by people that acutally can decide about them.

Then you‚Äôve come to the wrong place. This is the Signal community forum, which is a place for anyone with an interest in Signal to discuss things. The actual devs very rarely (almost never) participate in feature request discussions.

Herohtar:

The actual devs very rarely (almost never) participate in feature request discussions.

That‚Äôs right. Although they indeed take notice of them, AFAIK.
The more likes a thread (the original post) gets, the more relevant the request becomes; also to the devs.

Besides, personally I wouldn‚Äôt consider caring about minor visual issues being too serious. The Signal emoji pack has several of them and at this point of time it could give the impression that someone doesn‚Äôt know what he‚Äôs doing or doesn‚Äôt care about the asthetics. ;)

There are usually good arguments for every side. I think it‚Äôs a goodtthing that mkarg cares about his stickers very much
